transformed_texts:
I think the Catholic Church needs to make some significant changes. They're losing followers, and it's largely because they're not very accepting of many things. For instance, their stance on gay marriages, abortion, and birth control is really outdated. While I understand that they have strong views on these topics, I believe that if they adapted to a more modern way of thinking, they wouldn't be worried about losing their following. Many people are starting to reject the Church's views on these issues, and it's causing a lot of people to turn against them.

If you're someone who supports abortion or gay marriage, you might not feel comfortable in a community where these things are viewed as completely wrong. It's the same with other issues – if the Church doesn't agree with your values, you might not want to be part of their community. It's hard to see why they can't have female priests or allow priests to be married. I don't think it would have prevented the problems, but it might have made a difference.

I don't get why priests can't have families or lead a normal life outside of their devotion to God. The Catholic Church says priests are married to God, but so are many other people who have jobs and families. It's not like they're asking for a complete separation from the world; they just want to balance their work and personal life.

Honestly, I'm not opposed to the idea of gay marriage. In my opinion, being gay isn't something people choose consciously, so it's not fair to hold them accountable for it. I think it's wrong to say that a man and a woman can get married, but two people of the same sex can't. It's not a choice they make, and I don't think it's right to punish someone for how they're born. I haven't really thought deeply about this topic, but it seems pretty clear to me that it's wrong to discriminate against people based on their sexual orientation.

It's not like being gay is something people choose; they're just born that way. I mean, just like I was born straight, and that's not something I consciously chose. It's not fair to hold them responsible for something that's not in their control. I think it's wrong to put people on a pedestal, judging them for being gay.

I don't think the federal government should be involved in this issue, as it's not a matter of national security or moral values. They're overstepping their boundaries and imposing their opinions on people's personal lives. Gay people are who they are, and they shouldn't be punished for it.

It's pretty simple: if being gay isn't a choice, then why should the government have the right to intervene? It's not their place to dictate how people live their lives or who they love. I just don't think it's right to punish people for being themselves.

That's my two cents on the matter.

I truly believe that gay marriage should be legalized. The thing is, there's really no valid reason not to. People often think that homosexual couples pose a threat to the traditional family, but that's just not true. It's a completely different situation, and there are so many nuances to it that make it hard to compare the two. It's like saying heads and tails are the same thing - they're not.

When it comes to civil rights, gay couples are often left out. For example, when you're in a gay relationship, your partner can't be by your side in the hospital or visit you because they're not considered family. That just doesn't seem fair, especially when you're committed to spending the rest of your life with someone.

Scientific studies have shown that gay couples have the same rates of success and satisfaction as heterosexual couples. It's just a relationship, and it's the same thing. Where people get hung up is when they think that gay couples are asking for the right to get married in a church. But what they're really asking for is a marriage certificate, a legal document provided by the government. If you allow someone a civil union, why not a marriage?

It's like segregation - separate but unequal. Gay couples are the same in many ways, with the same roles and responsibilities in their relationships. People worry about adoption issues and community impact, but these are just excuses. What about children of gay couples? Can they really be any different from children of straight couples? In many places, like New York City, kids of gay parents face bullying and prejudice in public schools.

The federal government should take a stand and make gay marriage legal in every state. The amendment should be the opposite of what it is now. President Bush has strong views on gay marriage, but they're based on his personal beliefs, not fact. And let's be honest, morality is subjective and differs from person to person. To impose one group's morality on everyone else is unfair and hypocritical, especially when it comes to issues like the Pledge of Allegiance and separation of church and state.

Some people are anti-gay and anti-gay marriage because they think being gay is a choice or a personality defect, but that's just not true. The American Psychological Association has debunked that myth, and it's time we listened to the experts, not our neighbors or popular opinion.

So, I wanted to share something with you about my job at the hospital pharmacy over the summer. Just because a drug is prohibited doesn't mean it has no therapeutic benefits. In fact, if we're talking about making it available to the public, I firmly believe the answer is no - absolutely not. However, if we're discussing its potential use for medicinal purposes, then yes, I think it's definitely worth considering. 

Think about it, there are plenty of illicit substances that we use in pharmacies all the time, like oxycodone, Vicodin, and Percocets. These are controlled substances, but we use them because they have benefits and if we dismiss those benefits just because there's a stigma around marijuana, then I don't think that makes sense. 

I also don't think marijuana is comparable to alcohol, at least in terms of its potential for abuse. If you misuse alcohol, it can lead to serious issues, but the same thing can happen with marijuana. However, I do think it's worth integrating it into society gradually, rather than suddenly legalizing it. This way, people might learn to use it responsibly. 

One of the main reasons people have a negative perception of marijuana is that it's illegal. But let's be real, it's not as bad for you as heroin or cocaine. If we could break down that image and show that marijuana is not as terrible as everyone makes it out to be, then people might be more likely to use it responsibly, especially for medical purposes.

I think the church has really adapted to the 21st century, it's not as strict as it used to be. When I was younger, I used to go to church every Sunday, get all dressed up, and see my friends from private school. However, now they've introduced a 'teenager mass' that's only 30 minutes long, and people dress way more casually. You'd see people coming in their beach clothes straight from the beach, even during the morning masses where everyone used to dress up. It's become a lot more relaxed. 

One thing that really stands out to me is the change in dress code. People used to dress up, now they wear jeans or khakis. It's not a bad thing, it's just more casual. As for the church's inner workings, I'm not really aware of that, but I guess that's what it is now.

Regarding the recent scandals about the Catholic church and pedophilia, I don't think allowing female priests or married priests would have prevented these incidents. There are men who are married and still develop an attraction to young kids, so it's not about being allowed to get married or not. It's the individual's choice to become a priest, and I think that's a big part of the problem. 

I mean, there are other religions that allow priests to be married, like Seventh Heaven, and their priests are still reverends or ministers. If someone really wants to practice their faith and get married, then they might want to look into a different faith. I think the root of the problem is more genetic, and people are born with these tendencies. You can't change that through marriage, and it will usually come out eventually. If the church knew about it and tried to cover it up, then that's a whole different story, but I don't think that was the case in all situations.

I don't have much else to say about the Catholic church, but I do think it's worth noting that if they knew about it and tried to cover it up, that's shameful.

I was initially okay with the idea, but I think the country was still reeling from the 9/11 attacks. It seemed like we went to war in Iraq as a result of a series of pretexts. The Bush administration linked the Iraq war to Osama Bin Laden and the 9/11 attacks, claiming Saddam Hussein had WMDs, which was later proven to be false. This really got under my skin. I think the Bush administration was openly deceiving the American people, and despite the evidence, they've never owned up to it. Even Colin Powell, who presented evidence at the UN, later admitted he wasn't convinced of the evidence at the time. That raises serious questions about the administration's integrity and their disregard for the constitution. It seems they've been trying to erode it since 9/11. 

I believe they came into office with the intention of going to war. A former treasury secretary mentioned this in his book, suggesting that President Bush was driven by a desire for revenge against Saddam Hussein, which was also motivated by his father's administration. This was an underhanded way to achieve their goals.

I think it's time we moved on from this conflict, but withdrawing now would likely lead to chaos and more bloodshed. The alternative plan, which involves a coalition of surrounding nations to restore order, also raises concerns. I'm not convinced this will work in the long run because it'll raise issues about Iraq's sovereignty and the effectiveness of their government. The news reports indicate that the interim government is struggling, the parliament is ineffective, and radical elements are vying for control. It's a complex and fractious situation, and I'm not sure how to articulate my concerns in a polite way.

I've been thinking more about the war in Iraq, and I have to admit, it's been a bit of a struggle for me to keep up with everything. I mean, it's not even officially declared as a war, right? It feels like we went into it as a way to get back at Iraq for the 9/11 attacks, but that's just my opinion. To be honest, I'm not really well-versed on the details, but I know we're trying to establish a democracy there, which seems like a great goal, but it's a long process. And now, it's like we're staying for oil and resources too. That's just not a good enough reason to keep it going when it's causing so much distress. It's a tough spot, and I'm not sure what the best solution is.

On one hand, I feel like we should keep trying to help them build a democracy, but on the other hand, it's like we're trying to impose our own values and systems on them, which could make things worse. And with the way things are going, it's hard to see a clear end in sight. I'm worried that if we stay, we'll just be prolonging the suffering and creating more hatred towards the US. I'm not sure what the answer is, but I know it's not going to be easy.

I do think that we shouldn't call it a war anymore, though. I mean, we didn't declare it as a war through Congress, so it's not really a declared war, is it? And that's how it should be done, right? It's all just a big mess, and I'm not sure what the best way forward is.

It's hard for me because I know people I care about have family members over there, and it's tough to see them having to deal with all this. But at the same time, I feel like we're kind of destroying their lives and their culture. I'm not sure what the right thing to do is, but I know it's not going to be simple.

Honestly, I have my doubts about it being right for a state to make it legal. I believe it's more the church's decision, considering the constitution clearly states separation of church and state. It's explicitly mentioned, and I think trying to enforce any kind of power over it would be a direct defiance of what's already been established. 

I think it's not just about one particular set of people trying to make it illegal, but more about picking and choosing which church's beliefs to support over others. As we can see, many Catholics and Christians are against it, but it's not a unified stance across the board. I don't think it's the government's place to decide what the churches can and can't enforce.

Separation of church and state has been a fundamental aspect of the constitution, promoting religious tolerance in the US. Attempting to amend it would be contradictory to what's already been written and could essentially restrict the people rather than the government. I don't think that's right.

In my opinion, the federal government should stay out of this issue. I'm not sure why there's a push for an amendment, except that it aligns with the president's personal Catholic beliefs. This shows that he's favoring one religion over others, which I don't think is right. It's up to the churches to decide, not the president or any government official. There's no concrete reason for the amendment other than personal views, and I don't see how it would have a significant impact on the economy. 

If anything, it might have a positive effect on society. I think I've covered all my points.

Let's talk about the war in Iraq. To be honest, I think the government was not entirely truthful with the American people about the reasons for going to war. They tried to link the invasion of Iraq to the 9/11 terrorist attacks, but it's not that straightforward. The government capitalized on the public's outrage after 9/11 to justify the invasion, which started in 2003.

Personally, I've always been against war, especially when it comes to preemptive strikes. In many ways, the Iraq War is a repeat of the Vietnam War, and I think the government should've learned from its past mistakes. A huge number of American soldiers have lost their lives, which is heartbreaking.

The US government made a serious mistake by removing Iraq's government without being prepared for the aftermath. They tried to implant a democratic government, similar to what they attempted in Vietnam, but they didn't consider the long-term consequences. It's not an easy process to establish a stable democracy, and it's unrealistic to expect it to happen quickly. The US government made it seem like a relatively simple task, but in reality, it's a complex and challenging process.

One of the main issues is that the US got involved in a war without being prepared for the outcome. They're still in Iraq in 2006, and many American troops are still dying. The situation is a long way from being resolved, and it's clear that the US government wasn't prepared for the void of power and chaos that followed the removal of the Iraqi government.

It's hard to justify the continued involvement in Iraq when the government's initial reasons for going to war, such as the presence of WMDs, were proven false. North Korea, which actually had WMDs, didn't face the same level of aggression. It's clear that the US government is prioritizing its own interests, particularly access to oil resources, over the well-being of the people in Iraq.

It's difficult to make a decision on what to do next, but I hope that the conflict ends soon and there's peace in Iraq. However, given the current situation, it's hard to be optimistic.

Well, let me think for a moment. I'm strongly in favor of gay marriage, and I've always been that way. I genuinely believe it's a matter of personal preference, and something that's increasingly being shown to be influenced by biology rather than social factors. It's unfair to deny people rights based on something that's beyond their control. I'm a firm supporter of gay marriage, and I think it's inhumane to discriminate against individuals in this way.

In my opinion, governments and politics shouldn't interfere with this issue at all. It's a personal and private matter, not something that should be decided at the state or national level. I've seen it firsthand in my own community - there are openly gay couples living just like any other family, taking care of their daily responsibilities and living their lives without any issues. It's ridiculous that President Bush is trying to impose his own interpretation of marriage on the rest of us.

I've done some research, and it seems that there's a growing understanding that homosexuality may be linked to a chemical imbalance in the brain, rather than being a result of upbringing or environment. So, it's not necessarily something that's chosen, but rather something people are born with.

To me, the fact that straight couples can get married in secret without any fuss, but gay couples are put under a microscope, is a huge issue. It's something that should be a private, personal choice, not a public spectacle. I think it's time we treat all couples equally and respect their right to love and marry whoever they choose.

Honestly, when you post something online, it's essentially a public declaration. It's out there for anyone to see, and you can't take it back. As someone who's dealt with this in my role as an R.A., it's a reality you have to face. What you put out there can shape people's perceptions of you. If you're discussing sensitive topics like violence or extreme actions, someone's bound to take notice and share it. The internet is a global platform, and if you're connected to someone who receives that bulletin, they might react. Schools, for instance, can't ignore these warnings; they have to act on them to ensure everyone's safety. However, it's also challenging to discern what's serious and what's just a joke, especially when we've seen cases like the one that happened at our school, which could have been a twisted social experiment gone wrong. In this particular instance, someone overheard a comment and reported it to the school after researching the individual's online presence. They found concerning content that, in hindsight, was meant as a joke but took on a serious tone in the context. When you put something online, you lose control over who sees it and what they make of it. If you don't want it out there, don't post it. You can't dictate how people perceive you or what they take seriously. Schools shouldn't be monitoring students' online activities, but if concerns are raised, they do have a responsibility to investigate. It's a delicate balance between respecting students' privacy and ensuring their safety. I think school officials should focus on addressing issues raised by students, rather than actively searching for information. But if concerns are brought to their attention, they should take them seriously and act accordingly.

I'm getting the feeling that the war has dragged on for far too long. Initially, the goal was to restore democracy in another country, which was a noble cause. However, it seems like we've lost sight of that purpose a long time ago. It now feels like we're fighting just for the sake of it, to prove our military might, rather than for the original reason. I'm also concerned that the underlying motivations might have been questionable from the start, considering the complex history between George Bush's father and Saddam Hussein.

If our initial intention was to bring democracy to a country with no fair political system, that would have been a justifiable reason, but only if there were no personal interests involved. Unfortunately, I think our purpose has been distorted over time. I believe we made our point with the initial invasion, which was a significant statement in itself. However, the fact that the war has dragged on for over a year, maybe even years, is just too long.

If our goal was to bring democracy to a country ruled by a tyrant, that's a legitimate reason for war, but I don't think that's our reason anymore. It seems like we're still fighting for the sake of fighting, to avoid losing face or to claim a decisive victory. I genuinely think it's time to bring this to an end.

I believe it's been long enough for the local government to take responsibility for themselves. We've been pouring billions of dollars into this war, which could be better spent on our own pressing issues like poverty, public roads, schools, and healthcare. It's like we're sacrificing our own citizens for a cause that's been lost. Our economy is being drained, and I think it's time to stop this unnecessary expenditure.

War shouldn't be a long-term budget item. We have our own problems to address, like poverty and internal improvements. The money being spent on this war could be better spent on our own citizens' welfare. It's a shame that our own people are being put in harm's way for a cause that's no longer valid.

That's my two cents on the matter.

I had a thought and I wanted to clarify it.  It was stopped because someone went online and found that there was a potential issue.  I think it's fair to say that when you post information online, like on Myspace, you have to know that lots of people can see it.  Even though you have to accept someone as a friend before they can view your profile, you're essentially giving them permission to see it.  It's like this whenever you put anything online - you have to be aware that a lot of people are going to see it.

It's a tricky situation because on one hand, it's good that someone was able to catch that potential issue and prevent something bad from happening.  On the other hand, it does raise some questions about who should be monitoring these profiles and under what circumstances.  If they're just randomly looking at everyone's profiles, that's a different story than if they're actively looking for something specific.

Personally, I've had some concerns about privacy online.  I don't have a Myspace, but I do have a Facebook and I'm aware that there are people out there who might be looking at my stuff.  I've even seen a documentary or show about someone who was able to gather information about someone online and meet up with them in a short amount of time.  It's a bit unnerving, but at the same time, I don't want to limit my online presence too much because I value being able to communicate with friends.

It's a delicate balance, but I guess that's just the way it is when you're online.  I did hear about a school that banned students from having Myspace accounts, which I thought was a bit strange because I'm not sure how they had the authority to do that.

That's all I really have to say on the matter.

I'm a bit hesitant to bring this up, but I feel like I have to discuss the Iraq War. To be honest, I'm worried about sounding like one of those people who only speak out against it now, but I genuinely believe it was a bad idea from the start. The general consensus around the world, except within the administration, was that it was a flawed concept. It's pretty clear, given the recent polls. In the US, Iraq, and globally, a staggering 75-80% of people think it was a bad idea. Even a significant number of US troops currently in Iraq, around 70%, believe it was a mistake and that we should withdraw within a year. This disaster was already unfolding before our involvement, and now trying to pull out will only add to it. The cultural differences between the US and the Middle East are vast, making it extremely challenging, if not impossible, for our administration to impose democracy on a region that may not want it. We have to consider the potential consequences of invading a country, even if its leader was a ruthless dictator like Saddam. I think it's essential to weigh the pros and cons before making such a drastic decision. Withdrawing from Iraq is the most sensible option, considering the situation has only deteriorated since our involvement. I haven't heard any compelling arguments for staying, and I'm not convinced by the administration's suggestions for a gradual withdrawal. If they want to leave in stages over a year or more, I wouldn't object, but I just can't see a valid reason for prolonging our presence. It's ironic that around 80% of Iraqis think we should leave within a year, and a quarter believe we should leave immediately. If we're trying to help, it's worth considering their opinions, especially since they're the ones who'll be living with the consequences. If we ask them if we should leave and they say yes, then at least we can't be blamed if things go wrong. If we decide to help after leaving, we might at least be seen as the less-bad guys in the Middle East, which isn't saying much, but it's better than our current situation.

I've been thinking a lot about this, and I believe that gender discrimination is still a significant issue in the United States. It's not just a women's problem, though - it affects the specific field of work you're in. For me, I feel like women have it tougher because of the glass ceiling, even though we're supposed to have equality. It's hard to find people who are willing to work under a woman, especially when society has been conditioned to think otherwise for so long. Women often see a job they're qualified for, but the board might not promote them because historically, women haven't been in upper management. This isn't just a women's issue, though - the same thing happens to men in different industries, like fashion or being a stay-at-home parent.

It's not common for men to stay at home and take care of the kids, and when they do, people often look down on them because they think men should be the breadwinners. This can be really tough on them, especially if they've always dreamed of being with their kids and helping raise them. In the fashion industry, males are often judged based on their style and background, and if they don't fit the typical mold, people might question their expertise. It's not just about being a man or a woman, though - it's about being taken seriously in your field.

Changing this mindset is tough because society has a set way of thinking, and it's hard to change fast. But I think we're making progress, slowly. Women are becoming CEOs and getting more accepted in business, and men are staying at home to care for their kids. People are starting to realize that women might have the better job or that men can be stay-at-home dads. It's all about promoting the qualities of people who are often stereotyped against, without being too pushy. If you force it, people will resist, but if you show them the good qualities, they might start to accept it. We're at a good point now where it's starting to become enforced, and I'm not sure what more we can do that hasn't already been done.

It's not just about men and women, though - people from different backgrounds can be discriminated against too. For example, someone from a rural area might not have the best grammar, but they're incredibly intelligent and work their way up to a CEO position. Other men might look down on them because of their accent or lack of grammatical skills. It's not just about gender, either - it's about where you're from and how you're perceived. I think that's another example of how discrimination can work.

I think I've got a better understanding of the situation now - it's been decriminalized, not fully legalized. That means it's more like a traffic ticket, where you get cited instead of being arrested and taken in. However, people still worry about the long-term consequences, like job interviews and things like that, even after it's been decriminalized. On the other hand, arresting people for marijuana possession is expensive - it costs a lot to bring them in, book them, and let them go, not to mention the court costs and public defenders. Some places just can't afford that, so they're not willing to make the change, even if it would free up a lot of money for other important things like public education and social programs. 

In a place like Denver, where people are more open-minded, I think it's a good idea. It's freed up a lot of money that can be spent on things that really matter. But, it's not all good - there are still reasons why marijuana shouldn't be widely available, like the fact that it could be a problem if people start smoking and driving. Plus, it's still not widely accepted in a lot of places, so it would be awkward to have it out in the open like that.

I think it's also worth noting that marijuana can have a bigger impact on people's lifestyles than their motor skills, and that's not something you can generalize easily. People react to substances differently, and some people are naturally more responsible than others. But I do think that both marijuana and alcohol have their own negative effects. It's just hard to make a blanket statement about it when people are so different.

I'd say yes to the idea because it has a lot of traditional elements that have been around for a long time. It's great to be rooted in tradition, but it's also essential to be adaptable to change. One thing that comes to mind is the Catholic Church's weekly attendance requirement and their strict adherence to tradition. At times, I feel like the Church looks down on people who don't perfectly follow their doctrine, and they often don't accept those who aren't practicing Catholics exactly as they should be. This is evident in my own family's experience - my parents, who were from different religious backgrounds, couldn't get married in the Catholic Church because of my dad's Episcopalian faith.

It's hypocritical to preach love and acceptance while not practicing it. The Catholic teaching of loving others is a great message, but it's not always put into action. I believe the Church sticks to outdated practices, even when they contradict their own teachings. This inconsistency is a significant issue.

As for the idea of priests being allowed to marry, I'm not convinced it would make a significant difference in the way priests behave. People who are prone to child molestation would likely continue their behavior regardless of their marital status. It's not the same as being married to a consenting adult, and I don't think allowing priests to be married would be a deterrent.

Ultimately, I think the real issue is the power dynamic and the lack of accountability, not the fact that priests are celibate. Allowing priests to be married wouldn't necessarily change the underlying problems that lead to these horrific acts.

I'm still trying to wrap my head around this, but I haven't quite made up my mind yet. To be honest, I'm not sure who's right or wrong on this issue. However, I do think it's one of the trickiest topics we're dealing with right now. It's a delicate balance between separating church and state, and defining marriage is a complicated matter that can easily offend someone.

Honestly, I'm having a hard time figuring out whether marriage should be viewed as all civil unions or something more. I'm not sure if the government should be involved in defining it, considering it's often seen as a sacrament. If it were viewed as a civil union, people would still get tax breaks and the government wouldn't need to consider the specifics of the marriage. In my opinion, that's what it boils down to - two people committing to each other, without the government interfering with church and state.

The fact that gay marriage is involved makes it even more complicated. Essentially, it comes down to two people getting a civil union. If all states could come to a logical agreement, I think they should push to make it a federal law. However, a constitutional amendment to ban gay marriage just seems ridiculous. The constitution shouldn't be amended for a cause that's not significant enough. It's not a massive issue, and it shouldn't require such a drastic measure to define or ban it.

It's really not that important to amend the constitution just to deal with gay marriage. Put simply, it's just not worth it.

To be honest, I was raised in a Christian household, and for me, homosexuality is a complex issue. I have many gay friends, which has given me a different perspective on the matter. While I may not fully agree with a gay lifestyle, I strongly believe it should be legalized. I don't think it's something the federal government should dictate, but rather something each state should decide for itself.

It seems like many states have different political leanings, with some being more democratic and others more republican. In a democratic state, it's likely that gay marriage will be supported, and if you choose to live there, you're basically agreeing to abide by their laws. Therefore, I don't think you should disagree with the decision if a state decides to legalize gay marriage.

I do think that homosexuals should have the same rights and opportunities as heterosexuals, which is why I believe each state should be able to decide whether to legalize gay marriage. This way, it's up to the individual states to make their own decisions, rather than having a single president impose his views on the entire country.

I've already touched on this point, but I'll repeat myself: I don't think President Bush should have the power to dictate whether the whole country should be against gay marriage. I believe it's up to each individual state to decide how to govern itself. Since the president won't be in office forever, and his successor might have a different stance on the issue, it's best to leave it up to the states. That way, they'll have to live with the consequences of their decision, not the president.

As for whether a president should be able to impose their will on all states, I don't think so. They can't live in every state, so how could they possibly know what's best for each one? It's better to let the states decide their own fate.

To answer your question directly, I don't think it's right for the president to have that kind of power. It's just a matter of letting each state govern itself, and the president can focus on more pressing issues.

I'm not sure what you're getting at, but let me try to break it down. Myspace is a public platform where you post things for anyone to see, whether it's school officials or not. If you post something online, you have to accept that people will see it, regardless of whether they're from the school or not. In my opinion, if the school officials saw the post, they had every right to because even if it wasn't under the school's name, they could have accessed it from their homes.

As long as it helps prevent something like a school shooting, which is a school's responsibility, I think it's perfectly fine. If they're going on Myspace to check if students are doing things they shouldn't, like drinking or smoking, they're essentially fishing for trouble. But if it leads to making the school a safer place, I don't consider that an invasion of privacy.

It's similar to if they were to go on the internet to prevent students from doing things that put others in danger. If you post something on Myspace, not expecting to get in trouble, that's unrealistic. We all have to be careful about what we post online because it's there forever and can come back to haunt us. Even something you consider harmless can be used against you.

If a school official catches you doing something bad when you're a student, it's not an invasion of privacy when they take action. It's the same with the internet - once you post something, there's no taking it back. So if you're concerned about a school official seeing your post, maybe you shouldn't post it in the first place.

If the school officials are using the internet to make the school a safer place, I think that's okay. It's similar to what we did in my high school, where we had lockdown drills and practices to prepare for emergencies. The school officials were just doing the same thing - taking steps to prevent anything bad from happening.

That's basically my point - it's a public platform, and if you post something online, you have to accept the consequences.

Okay, I've been thinking more about this, and I have to admit that my initial feelings about the war have changed. To be honest, I was really passionate about it at first because it hit close to home after 9/11. I wanted to make a difference and show them what we'd been through. But looking back, I think we jumped into it without a clear plan and without thinking about the long-term consequences. We were so caught up in the emotions and anger that we overlooked some major things.

I genuinely believe that we've been there for too long without making significant progress. The more I see, the more I think that the people over there are their own worst enemies. As long as they're busy fighting with each other, they're not going to be a threat to us. The war has just become a never-ending cycle, and I'm not convinced it's doing much good.

My feelings have definitely shifted, and I'm now more against the war than I was for it. I don't think we're the right people to try to change them; they've been that way for too long. I'm not saying we should have just left them to their problems, but a more thoughtful approach might have been better. We were so caught up in the desire for revenge that we didn't think things through.

To be honest, I think President Bush's decision to declare war on Iraq was also a bit impulsive. I understand where he was coming from at the time, but I think we should have been more careful about how we approached it. We rushed in without a clear plan, and that's led to a lot of confusion and problems.

I still think we did what we had to do, but I wish we'd done it more thoughtfully. We're not going to be able to change them; they're too entrenched in their ways. I'm not sure how much longer we can keep going on with this. We're not making enough progress, and when we leave, things will probably just fall apart. It's time for us to reevaluate our strategy and consider coming home.
